Detailed Description

This file contains the header file information for the Serial Peripheral (UART/SER) API.

Author:
Imagination Technologies
Copyright 2006 by Imagination Technologies Limited.
All rights reserved. No part of this software, either material or conceptual may be copied or distributed, transmitted, transcribed, stored in a retrieval system or translated into any human or computer language in any form by any means, electronic, mechanical, manual or other-wise, or disclosed to the third parties without the express written permission of Imagination Technologies Limited, Home Park Estate, Kings Langley, Hertfordshire, WD4 8LZ, U.K.

Define Documentation

#define SER_INF_TIMEOUT   -1

Infinite wait (do not time out).

#define SER_ASYNC_GET_RESULT ( async,
context   ) 

Value:

{ (async)->forget = 0;                     \
      (async)->callback_context = (context); }
Async descriptor helper macro used to get result of async operation.

#define SER_ASYNC_FORGET ( async   ) 

Value:

{ (async)->forget = 1; \
      (async)->callback_routine = NULL; }
Async descriptor helper macro used to ignore result of async operation.

#define SER_ASYNC_CALLBACK ( async,
routine,
context   ) 

Value:

{ (async)->forget = 1; \
      (async)->callback_routine = routine; \
      (async)->callback_context = context; }
Async descriptor helper macro used to register a callback routine to collect the result of an async operation.

Typedef Documentation

typedef void SER_CALLBACKROUTINE_T(void *context, unsigned char *buffer, unsigned long num_bytes_to_transfer, unsigned long num_bytes_transferred, unsigned long status)

The callback function provides a way for the device driver/API to notify the calling application of I/O completion. The driver does not require the callback function to provide any specific function, but it must not use any MeOS functions that would require a scheduling operation.

Parameters:
*context Pointer to private context for the callback.
*buffer Pointer to buffer where data was transferred to/from.
num_bytes_to_transfer Number of bytes that serial port was programmed to transfer.
num_bytes_transferred Number of bytes actually transferred.
status Status code describing the completion status of the transaction:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS - Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL - Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT - Operation was timed out.

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum SER_STATUS_CODES

These define the status codes that are returned by SER API functions.

Enumerator:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS  Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_PORT  Invalid port number.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_WORDFORMAT  Invalid word format.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_CTSRTS  Invalid CTS/RTS setting.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_THRESHOLD  Invalid receiver FIFO trigger threshold.
SER_STATUS_CONFIG_FAILED  Port configuration failed.
SER_STATUS_ERROR  An error occurs during the operation.
SER_STATUS_OVERRUN_ERROR  An overrun error occurs during the operation.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL  Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT  Operation was timed out.
SER_STATUS_WOULD_BLOCK  Asynchronous I/O has been requested, but the routine would need to block.

enum SER_FORMATS

These enumerations define serial port word formats. They are used in the 'format' field in the SER_SETTINGS_T structure. Note that 'sticky' parity is not supported in this API as it is not a particularly useful data format.

Enumerator:
SER_FORMAT_B5S1P0  Set format to 5 bits, 1 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S1P0  Set format to 6 bits, 1 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S1P0  Set format to 7 bits, 1 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S1P0  Set format to 8 bits, 1 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B5S2P0  Set format to 5 bits, 2 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S2P0  Set format to 6 bits, 2 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S2P0  Set format to 7 bits, 2 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S2P0  Set format to 8 bits, 2 stop, no parity.
SER_FORMAT_B5S1PODD  Set format to 5 bits, 1 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S1PODD  Set format to 6 bits, 1 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S1PODD  Set format to 7 bits, 1 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S1PODD  Set format to 8 bits, 1 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B5S2PODD  Set format to 5 bits, 2 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S2PODD  Set format to 6 bits, 2 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S2PODD  Set format to 7 bits, 2 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S2PODD  Set format to 8 bits, 2 stop, odd parity.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED0  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED1  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED2  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED3  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED4  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED5  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED6  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_RESERVED7  Reserved.
SER_FORMAT_B5S1PEVEN  Set format to 5 bits, 1 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S1PEVEN  Set format to 6 bits, 1 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S1PEVEN  Set format to 7 bits, 1 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S1PEVEN  Set format to 8 bits, 1 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B5S2PEVEN  Set format to 5 bits, 2 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B6S2PEVEN  Set format to 6 bits, 2 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B7S2PEVEN  Set format to 7 bits, 2 stop, even parity.
SER_FORMAT_B8S2PEVEN  Set format to 8 bits, 2 stop, even parity.

enum SER_RXTHRESHOLDS

These enumerations define RX FIFO trigger thresholds. They are used in the 'rxthreshold' field in the SER_SETTINGS_T structure.

Enumerator:
SER_RXTHRESHOLD_1  Trigger with 1 byte in the FIFO.
SER_RXTHRESHOLD_4  Trigger with 4 bytes in the FIFO.
SER_RXTHRESHOLD_8  Trigger with 8 bytes in the FIFO.
SER_RXTHRESHOLD_14  Trigger with 14 bytes in the FIFO.

enum SER_FLOW_CONTROL

These enumerations define the flow control type.

Enumerator:
SER_FLOW_CONTROL_NONE  No flow control
SER_FLOW_CONTROL_CTSRTS  Hardware CTS/RTS

Function Documentation

img_void SERDefine ( ioblock_sBlockDescriptor *  psBlockDescriptor  ) 

Description:
This function defines an instance of a UART block.

unsigned long SERInit ( SER_PORT_T *  port,
unsigned char  port_number,
signed long  use_cts_rts,
SER_SETTINGS_T *  port_settings,
SER_IO_BLOCK_T *  io_blocks,
unsigned long  num_io_blocks 
)

Description:
This function is used to initialise the Serial Port. It should be called before carrying out a serial port transaction by calling SERRead() or SERWrite(). It is not necessary to re-initialise the port before further transactions unless any of the parameters set at initialisation are to be altered.

Most of the parameters set up at the initialisation stage are provided in the port_settings input argument. This contains the baud rate divisor, data format, RX FIFO trigger threshold and serial port reference clock select.

The 'use_cts_rts' flag determines whether or not CTS/RTS flow control is used and is passed in as a seperate argument. The number of the serial port to be used is also passed to this initialisation function.

Following initialisation, the port descriptor (SER_PORT_T) can be used with other API functions to identify the initialised serial port.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
port_number Port number.
use_cts_rts Flag controlling CTS/RTS flow control.
0 disables CTS/RTS.
1 enables CTS/RTS.
*port_settings Pointer to port configuration options.
*io_blocks I/O blocks (required for asynchronous I/O).
num_io_blocks Number of I/O blocks.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_PORT Invalid port number.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_CTSRTS Invalid CTS/RTS setting.
SER_STATUS_CONFIG_FAILED Port configuration failed.

unsigned long SERDeinit ( SER_PORT_T *  port  ) 

Description:
This function is used to deinitialise the serial API, and should be used as part of a safe system shutdown.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_INVALID_PORT Invalid port number.

unsigned long SERRead ( SER_PORT_T *  port,
unsigned char *  buffer,
unsigned long  num_bytes_to_read,
unsigned long *  num_bytes_read,
SER_ASYNC_T *  async,
long  timeout 
)

Description:
This function is used to carry out a read transaction. When it is called, the Serial Port is set up ready to read in data. When the device it is connected to transmits data, it is received by the serial port and stored in incrementing memory locations, starting at the address specified in the 'buffer' input argument.
Once the port has received 'num_bytes_to_read' bytes, the function completes.
The 'num_bytes_read' variable is updated with the number of bytes received.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
*buffer Pointer to received data buffer.
num_bytes_to_read Number of bytes to read from UART.
*num_bytes_read Updated each time a byte is successfully received, giving a count of the number of bytes read from the slave. This is ONLY updated for synchronous operation.
*async Pointer to asynchronous I/O descriptor if a non-blocking transfer is required (else NULL).
timeout Number of MeOS timer ticks before operation times out. Set to SER_INF_TIMEOUT for an infinite period of time. The timer starts when QIO start function is called. This parameter has the same implication for blocking and non-blocking transfers.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT Operation timed out.
SER_STATUS_WOULD_BLOCK Asynchronous I/O has been requested, but the routine would need to block.
Note: This routine will always return successfully if asynchronous I/O is requested.

unsigned long SERWrite ( SER_PORT_T *  port,
unsigned char *  buffer,
unsigned long  num_bytes_to_write,
unsigned long *  num_bytes_written,
SER_ASYNC_T *  async,
long  timeout 
)

Description:
This function is used to carry out a write transaction. When it is called, the Serial Port transmits data from incrementing memory locations, starting at the address specified in the 'buffer' input argument.
Once the port has transmitted 'num_bytes_to_write' bytes, the function completes.
The 'num_bytes_written' variable is updated with the number of bytes transmitted.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
*buffer Pointer to buffer containing data to be transmitted.
num_bytes_to_write Number of bytes to write.
*num_bytes_written Updated each time a byte is successfully transmitted, giving a count of the number of bytes written to the slave. This is ONLY updated for synchronous operation.
*async Pointer to asynchronous I/O descriptor if a non-blocking transfer is required (else NULL).
timeout Number of MeOS timer ticks before operation times out. Set to SER_INF_TIMEOUT for an infinite period of time. The timer starts when QIO start function is called. This parameter has the same implication for blocking and non-blocking transfers.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT Operation timed out.
SER_STATUS_WOULD_BLOCK Asynchronous I/O has been requested, but the routine would need to block.
Note: This routine will always return successfully if asynchronous I/O is requested.

unsigned long SERGetReadResult ( SER_PORT_T *  port,
unsigned long *  num_bytes_read,
void **  context,
signed long  block,
long  timeout 
)

Description:
This function gets the result of an asynchronous read operation. It can be called after an SER read transaction has been carried out. The function is passed the SER_PORT_T descriptor for the port it is retrieving the result from. It determines the number of bytes read in and updates the contents of the num_bytes_read pointer passed to it. It also returns a status code describing the way in which the transaction completed.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
*num_bytes_read Updated with the number of bytes read.
**context Updated with the pointer to the context of the transaction it is retrieving the result from.
block Blocking flag. 1 to block, 0 not to block.
timeout Timeout to use when blocking. Number of MeOS timer ticks before operation times out. Set to SER_INF_TIMEOUT for an infinite period of time.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT Operation timed out.
SER_STATUS_WOULD_BLOCK No transaction has completed.

unsigned long SERGetWriteResult ( SER_PORT_T *  port,
unsigned long *  num_bytes_written,
void **  context,
signed long  block,
long  timeout 
)

Description:
This function gets the result of an asynchronous write operation. It can be called after an SER write transaction has been carried out. The function is passed the SER_PORT_T descriptor for the port it is retrieving the result from. It determines the number of bytes written and updates the contents of the num_bytes_written pointer passed to it. It also returns a status code describing the way in which the transaction completed.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
*num_bytes_written Updated with the number of bytes written.
**context Updated with the pointer to the context of the transaction it is retrieving the result from.
block Blocking flag. 1 to block, 0 not to block.
timeout Timeout to use when blocking. Number of MeOS timer ticks before operation times out. Set to SER_INF_TIMEOUT for an infinite period of time.
Returns:
This function returns as follows:
SER_STATUS_SUCCESS Operation completed successfully.
SER_STATUS_CANCEL Operation was cancelled.
SER_STATUS_TIMEOUT Operation timed out.
SER_STATUS_WOULD_BLOCK No transaction has completed.

void SERCancelRead ( SER_PORT_T *  port  ) 

Description:
This function cancels all read operations queued on the connected device, resets the driver from any error flag previously detected and flushes the hardware receiver FIFO. The function is passed the SER_PORT_T descriptor for the transaction it is cancelling.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
Returns:
none.

void SERCancelWrite ( SER_PORT_T *  port  ) 

Description:
This function cancels all write operations queued on the connected device. The function is passed the SER_PORT_T descriptor for the transaction it is cancelling.

Parameters:
*port Pointer to port descriptor.
Returns:
none.
